item.title: Issue: REST Middleware: Is SignalR attempting to connect for the first time or reconnect - @Dprosevski
item.description:
Help us make content visible

I searched for reconnection, reconnecting, reconnect, signalr, http and similar

Describe the new topic

this.hubConn = new HubConnectionBuilder().withUrl("https://server/hubEndPoint}", { skipNegotiation: true, transport: HttpTransportType.WebSockets }).withAutomaticReconnect()

When SignalR attempts to start the connection with the server using "HttpTransportType.WebSockets", it makes a "GET" call to the server to start it. My middleware intercepts the GET call and I see all the variables of the context (request, headers etc.). However on the reconnect (triggered by "withAutomaticReconnect()") SignalR makes another GET call to reconnect to the same URL it was initially built with. So my middleware on the server side intercepts it again. And that is all fine, the issue is that I see NOTHING that is telling me that this second request is made because of reconnection.

Possible solution would be to add something to Request.Headers that would tell the user if the GET call for SignalR is for connection or reconnection.

item.title: Issue: Instructions off about Database Name - @kevingates
item.description:

In SSOX, select (localdb)\MSSQLLocalDB > Databases > SchoolContext-{GUID}. The database name is generated from the context name provided earlier plus a dash and a GUID.

as your documentation says.

I'm using .Net 6. Not sure why the discrepancy.

item.title: Issue: Call out disabling web.config transform - @guardrex
item.description:
The article makes reference in one or two spots to using a custom web.config, but it doesn't indicate disabling a transform of a custom file ...

<PropertyGroup>
  <IsTransformWebConfigDisabled>true</IsTransformWebConfigDisabled>
</PropertyGroup>

--- OR --- because a copy target will just overwrite a file generated by the SDK with the dev's custom file ---

<Target Name="CopyWebConfig" AfterTargets="Publish">
  <Copy SourceFiles="web.config" DestinationFolder="$(PublishDir)" />
</Target>

... which we need in this topic because we don't necessarily expect WASM devs to look much at the main IIS host and delpoy topics in the main doc set in the same way we expect Blazor Server devs to look.

As part of this work, assess how this topic indicates that the main content IIS coverage does apply to hosted WASM scenarios.

Cross-refs:

  • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/host-and-deploy/iis/web-config?view=aspnetcore-6.0#webconfig-file-location
  • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/host-and-deploy/iis/transform-webconfig?view=aspnetcore-6.0#prevent-webconfig-transformation

Document Details

item.title: Issue: Kestrel as a Reverse Proxy Supporting HTTP/2 - @ChinnPlan
item.description:
We are looking into use gRPC to connect to our EDMS (M-Files). Our clients would use the M-Files desktop client to connect to a reverse proxy in the DMZ that would direct requests to the M-Files application server in the internal network. So far, I have only heard of this working with proxy servers running on Linux (eg. HAProxy, NGINX), because M-Files requires HTTP/2 in this configuration. I have heard that Application Request Routing using HTTP/2 is not yet supported in IIS. Is this still true? Or does using Kestrel provide a suitable way to do this in Windows?

Document Details

item.title: Issue: SqlException: Invalid column name 'Rating - @Jwace
item.description:
Hi,

I followed ASP.NET Core MVC tutorial and I'm stuck at the end of part 8 with this issue : "SqlException: Invalid column name 'Rating'."

It seems that the problem is located into MoviesController.cs:

MvcMovie.Controllers.MoviesController.Index(string movieGenre, string searchString) in MoviesController.cs + 42. var movieGenreVM = new MovieGenreViewModel

But my following code is exactly the same as in tutorial:

using System;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.Linq;
using System.Threading.Tasks;
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc;
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Rendering;
using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore;
using MvcMovie.Data;
using MvcMovie.Models;

namespace MvcMovie.Controllers
{
    public class MoviesController : Controller
    {
        private readonly MvcMovieContext _context;

        public MoviesController(MvcMovieContext context)
        {
            _context = context;
        }


        // GET: Movies
        public async Task<IActionResult> Index(string movieGenre, string searchString)
        {
            // Use LINQ to get list of genres.
            IQueryable<string> genreQuery = from m in _context.Movie
                                            orderby m.Genre
                                            select m.Genre;
            var movies = from m in _context.Movie
                         select m;

            if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(searchString))
            {
                movies = movies.Where(s => s.Title!.Contains(searchString));
            }

            if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(movieGenre))
            {
                movies = movies.Where(x => x.Genre == movieGenre);
            }

            var movieGenreVM = new MovieGenreViewModel
            {
                Genres = new SelectList(await genreQuery.Distinct().ToListAsync()),
                Movies = await movies.ToListAsync()
            };

            return View(movieGenreVM);
        }

        // GET: Movies/Details/5
        public async Task<IActionResult> Details(int? id)
        {
            if (id == null || _context.Movie == null)
            {
                return NotFound();
            }

            var movie = await _context.Movie
                .FirstOrDefaultAsync(m => m.Id == id);
            if (movie == null)
            {
                return NotFound();
            }

            return View(movie);
        }

        // GET: Movies/Create
        public IActionResult Create()
        {
            return View();
        }

        // POST: Movies/Create
        // To protect from overposting attacks, enable the specific properties you want to bind to.
        // For more details, see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=317598.
        [HttpPost]
        [ValidateAntiForgeryToken]
        public async Task<IActionResult> Create([Bind("Id,Title,ReleaseDate,Genre,Price,Rating")] Movie movie)
        {
            if (ModelState.IsValid)
            {
                _context.Add(movie);
                await _context.SaveChangesAsync();
                return RedirectToAction(nameof(Index));
            }
            return View(movie);
        }

        // GET: Movies/Edit/5
        public async Task<IActionResult> Edit(int? id)
        {
            if (id == null || _context.Movie == null)
            {
                return NotFound();
            }

            var movie = await _context.Movie.FindAsync(id);
            if (movie == null)
            {
                return NotFound();
            }
            return View(movie);
        }

        // POST: Movies/Edit/5
        // To protect from overposting attacks, enable the specific properties you want to bind to.
        // For more details, see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=317598.
        [HttpPost]
        [ValidateAntiForgeryToken]
        public async Task<IActionResult> Edit(int id, [Bind("Id,Title,ReleaseDate,Genre,Price,Rating")] Movie movie)
        {
            if (id != movie.Id)
            {
                return NotFound();
            }

            if (ModelState.IsValid)
            {
                try
                {
                    _context.Update(movie);
                    await _context.SaveChangesAsync();
                }
                catch (DbUpdateConcurrencyException)
                {
                    if (!MovieExists(movie.Id))
                    {
                        return NotFound();
                    }
                    else
                    {
                        throw;
                    }
                }
                return RedirectToAction(nameof(Index));
            }
            return View(movie);
        }

        // GET: Movies/Delete/5
        public async Task<IActionResult> Delete(int? id)
        {
            if (id == null || _context.Movie == null)
            {
                return NotFound();
            }

            var movie = await _context.Movie
                .FirstOrDefaultAsync(m => m.Id == id);
            if (movie == null)
            {
                return NotFound();
            }

            return View(movie);
        }

        // POST: Movies/Delete/5
        [HttpPost, ActionName("Delete")]
        [ValidateAntiForgeryToken]
        public async Task<IActionResult> DeleteConfirmed(int id)
        {
            if (_context.Movie == null)
            {
                return Problem("Entity set 'MvcMovieContext.Movie'  is null.");
            }
            var movie = await _context.Movie.FindAsync(id);
            if (movie != null)
            {
                _context.Movie.Remove(movie);
            }
            
            await _context.SaveChangesAsync();
            return RedirectToAction(nameof(Index));
        }

        private bool MovieExists(int id)
        {
          return _context.Movie.Any(e => e.Id == id);
        }
    }
}

Could you please help me ?

Détails du document

item.title: Issue: Standardize Blazor byte abbreviation conventions - @guardrex
item.description:
@Rick-Anderson @wadepickett

I raised this❓a couple of times over the years about removing the confusion on KB, MB, and GB. Devs get confused, for example, knowing if 1 KB is 1,000 bytes or 1,024 bytes. My remarks on this go back as far as the old issue (2017! ) ...

Beefing up my (mis)understandings on contribution guidelines https://github.com/dotnet/AspNetCore.Docs/issues/2617

... and that brings up a few fun memories .

The style manual only hints that they want to avoid embracing the standard that's been out for like 20 years now ...

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/style-guide/a-z-word-list-term-collections/term-collections/bits-bytes-terms

Technically per IEC and SI, we should be using "KiB" (kibibyte), "MiB" (mebibyte), and "GiB" (gibibyte) to eliminate the confusion ...

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_1541-2002

Since they won't permit that approach, I've been hardening docs for several years using either of the following techniques ...

  • Place the exact number of bytes in parentheses after the mention ... "The default is 32 KB (32,768 bytes)."
  • Show the calculated number of bytes ... "The default is 32 KB (32 * 1024)."

I would prefer to standardize on one of those and not drop the clarification entirely. I think it makes it sooooo much plainer what we mean ... it's perfectly clear in light of avoiding the standard.

I don't think you care if I continue using a technique in Blazor docs, but what do you think about those two approaches? Do you like one better than the other?

UPDATE: I'm going to explain that these abbreviations use the non-standard convention in the Fundamentals overview and drop my conventions from the individual topics.

Still tho, I wish one day that MS/.NET foundation would adopt the IEC/SI standard on this. It's silly to me that in 20 years people are still going to be confused by what these docs state.

Document Details

⚠ Do not edit this section. It is required for learn.microsoft.com ➟ GitHub issue linking.

  • ID: 618e1209-44b8-c367-13e7-fbcfc26b07ea
  • Version Independent ID: 618e1209-44b8-c367-13e7-fbcfc26b07ea
  • Content: ASP.NET Core Blazor fundamentals
  • Content Source: aspnetcore/blazor/fundamentals/index.md
  • Product: aspnet-core
  • Technology: aspnetcore-fundamentals
  • GitHub Login: @guardrex
  • Microsoft Alias: riande

item.title: Issue: Is this misleading? - @SQL-MisterMagoo
item.description:
In this section : https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/blazor/components/?view=aspnetcore-6.0#use-key-to-control-the-preservation-of-elements-and-components

When rendering a list of elements or components and the elements or components subsequently change, Blazor must decide which of the previous elements or components can be retained and how model objects should map to them. Normally, this process is automatic and can be ignored, but there are cases where you may want to control the process.

This is misleading as it suggests that Blazor will "get it right" most of the time and that is good enough. The truth is that preservation of elements/components rendered in a list/loop in Blazor is only guaranteed by use of the @key directive - as noted further down the page, but only if the reader gets that far.

Use of @key guarantees the preservation of elements or components based on the key's value.

The reason I am raising this issue is because of the number of times developers are still not using the @key and posting questions on SO about why they are seeing strange behaviour in loops.

Suggestion:

Change the wording in that opening section

When rendering a list of elements or components and the elements or components subsequently change, Blazor must decide which of the previous elements or components can be retained and how model objects should map to them. Without use of the @key directive, this process is automatic based on ordering of the rendered items. However, there are many cases where you may want to control the process.

Document Details

⚠ Do not edit this section. It is required for learn.microsoft.com ➟ GitHub issue linking.

item.title: Issue: Clarification request in "Configure Windows Authentication in ASP.NET Core" - @Notheisz57
item.description:
Regarding the Kestrel section of this document, specifically the warning and info blockquotes near the start of the section.

For the warning blockquote, I was working through a new project targeting .NET 6.0 and found NTLM/Kerberos credential persistence was not enabled by default. It may be beneficial to mention whether or not the code sample that follows results in the scenario described in the warning blockquote. If you create a new Razor/Blazor project from template and deploy it to an IIS server, would credential persistence be an issue? These kinds of examples are sometimes included in Microsoft Docs and I find them very informative, or at the very least they help understand the context, etc.

For the info blockquote, it is implied that if the platform/server supports Windows/Negotiate authentication natively, magic and smoke will pester you to enable the native implementation (rather than performing the authentication "in-process"?). Could this be better detailed or an example be included to clarify what this pertains to? If you create a new Razor/Blazor project from template and deploy it to an IIS server, would you receive this error if IIS has Windows Authentication disabled?

If clarification on these two blockquotes can be provided, I can author a change to the doc if suitable.

Document Details

item.title: Issue: DotNetObjectReference multiple instances created, only last one disposed - @omuleanu
item.description:
Hi, in this code:

@page "/call-dotnet-example-2"
...
    <button @onclick="TriggerDotNetInstanceMethod">
        Trigger .NET instance method
...
@code {
  ...
    public async Task TriggerDotNetInstanceMethod()
    {
        objRef = DotNetObjectReference.Create(this);
        result = await JS.InvokeAsync<string>("sayHello1", objRef);
    }
    public void Dispose()
    {
        objRef?.Dispose();
    }
}

You're calling DotNetObjectReference.Create on each button click, so Dispose will only execute on the last created instance. Is that an issue ?

Document Details

  • ID: 0eb4d762-3910-2c57-8741-3306c15537b6

item.title: Issue: Areas and _ViewImports.cshtml - @cthompson92
item.description:
Wanted to ask a question, because I couldn't decipher the answer from the docs page.

Given this project structure:

.
+-- Views
|   +-- _ViewImports.cshtml
+-- Areas
|   +-- Area1
|       +-- Views
|           +-- MyView.cshtml
|           +-- _ViewImports.cshtml

Would the imports defined in Views/_ViewImports.cshtml be applied to Areas/Area1/Views/MyView.cshtml ? In other words, is the _ViewImports.cshtml file at the root Views folder effectively 'global', or does a _ViewImports.cshtml file need to be created in each Area if there are imports that you want to make available to all view files in the project?

Document Details

item.title: Issue: New Blazor JS interop - @guardrex
item.description:
Per https://github.com/dotnet/blazor-samples/issues/41 ...

there is new JavaScript interop available for .Net 7.

I created simple demo to show the new JavaScript interop in Blazor.

I'm not sure if you want to adopt it as is, but perhaps you could have look at it and extend one of the existing sample apps.

https://github.com/pavelsavara/blazor-wasm-hands-pose

There is also non-Blazor demo which has more complex interop logic

https://github.com/pavelsavara/dotnet-wasm-todo-mvc

(also please ping me on IM to discuss how to collaborate on further docs about the feature, thank you)

It's best if we have a section and extend the snippet sample apps, as opposed to adding a new sample app. Every sample app adds overhead costs ☹️.

cc: @pavelsavara

item.title: Issue: Good page, my issue wasn't too complex, here are the details for my issue. - @donrolling
item.description:
I was having a lot of issues with my service. It wouldn't start. This page helped me get to the bottom of it.

I needed this nuget package: Microsoft.Extensions.Hosting.WindowsServices

Set the base path if we're in windows

.ConfigureAppConfiguration((context, builder) =>
{
	if (OperatingSystem.IsWindows())
	{
		builder.SetBasePath(AppContext.BaseDirectory);
	}
	var path = "appsettings.json";
	builder.AddJsonFile(path, optional: false, reloadOnChange: true);
})

and this UseWindowsService if we're running in windows, that was it!

if (OperatingSystem.IsWindows())
{
    hostBuilder.UseWindowsService();
}

Document Details

⚠ Do not edit this section. It is required for docs.microsoft.com ➟ GitHub issue linking.

  • ID: b0bd8cb8-7e28-8c4d-a550-3aea8f3ab4dd

  • Content Source: aspnetcore/host-and-deploy/windows-service.md

  • Technology: aspnetcore-hostdeploy

item.title: Issue: Named and Typed HttpClient ambiguity - @Michael-Ziluck
item.description:
Right now the docs for Named and Typed HttpClients are their own h2 section. However only the Named HttpClient section has a call-out about the necessity for the Microsoft.Extensions.Http package.

It would probably be helpful for some users (myself included prior to finding (https://github.com/dotnet/AspNetCore.Docs/issues/18541) to have both sections include the call out or to change the hierarchy to something kinda like:

  • h2: Custom HttpClients:
    • You can also provide custom HttpClients either by using a named HttpClient using an IHttpClientFactory, or by using a typed HttpClient that injects the global HttpClient.
    • {{Alert about package goes here}}
    • h3: Named HttpClient with IHttpClientFactory
      • ...
    • h3: Typed HttpClient
      • ...

item.title: Issue: Lazy-loading CSS files - @Michael-Ziluck
item.description:
This page does a great job explaining how to LazyLoad DLLs in a project. What it doesn't touch on however is how you lazy-load static assets from within said DLLs.

Say my RCL has a reference to another project (in my case MatBlazor). How would I go about loading the necessary CSS and JS files into my app without needing to eager load the CSS.

I'm not sure if this is better presented as a feature request but I would be surprised if such functionality does not already exist.

Thanks!

item.title: Issue: Description of first render lifecycle seems wrong - @glatzert
item.description:
Regarding our experiences and BlazorComponent Code, the description about the lifecycle is wrong regarding rendering during initialization. Especially the note itself contradicts the statement above.

It says the task is awaited, then it's rendered. Truth seems to be: the task is NOT awaitet and the component is rendered.

Component lifecycle events:

If the component is rendering for the first time on a request: Create the component's instance. Perform property injection. Run SetParametersAsync. Call OnInitialized{Async}. If an incomplete Task is returned, the Task is awaited and then the component is rerendered. Call OnParametersSet{Async}. If an incomplete Task is returned, the Task is awaited and then the component is rerendered. Render for all synchronous work and complete Tasks. Note

Asynchronous actions performed in lifecycle events might not have completed before a component is rendered. For more information, see the Handle incomplete async actions at render section later in this article.

Document Details

⚠ Do not edit this section. It is required for docs.microsoft.com ➟ GitHub issue linking.

  • ID: a970fb72-3dd0-d173-585d-2ccdd7923f81
  • Version Independent ID: 4871f4f7-9cf6-ac7a-0f21-c65d34bd1119
  • Content: ASP.NET Core Razor component lifecycle
  • Content Source: aspnetcore/blazor/components/lifecycle.md
  • Product: aspnet-core
  • Technology: aspnetcore-blazor
  • GitHub Login: @guardrex
  • Microsoft Alias: riande
